facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 252 of 1954 is an appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated 22nd January 1953 of the Election Tribunal, Vellore in Election Petition No. 35 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 252 of 1954. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 22nd January 1953 of the Election Tribunal, Vellore in Election Petition No. 35 of 1952.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on March 29, 1955 by SINHA J.

anchor.surface_text: 1955. March 29. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA. J.-The only question for determination in this appeal by special leave is whether the appellant is disqualified-

facts.text: Election Tribunal, North Arcot, Vellore held by orders dated 20th January 1953 that appellant disqualified under section 7(d) of Representation of the People Act, 1951 for election to House of the People.

anchor.surface_text: The only question for determination in this appeal by special leave is whether the appellant is disqualified-under section 7 d  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951  hereinafter called the Act  for election to the House of the People, as held by the Election Tribunal, North Arcot, Vellore, by its orders dated the 20th January, 1953 in Election Petition No. 35 of 1952.

facts.text: Facts of the case not in dispute and lie within narrow compass.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of this case are number in dispute and lie within a narrow companypass.

facts.text: Appellant and respondents 1 to 3 contested the last general elections from Dharmapuri Parliamentary Constituency in Salem district, Madras State.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and respondents I to 3 companytested the last general elections from the Dharmapuri Parliamentary Constituency in the district of Salem in the State of Madras.

facts.text: Respondents 4 to 10 added subsequently by Tribunal order, were candidates, nominations valid, withdrew candidature before polling.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 4 to 10 who were added subsequently by an order of the Tribunal were also candidates for election. Their numberinations also had been held to be valid but they ultimately withdrew their candidature before the polling took place.

facts.text: Appellant declared elected to the House of the People.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was in due companyrse declared to have been elected to the House of the People.

facts.text: 1st respondent filed election petition on 5th March 1952 before Election Tribunal contesting appellant's election on ground disqualified under section 7(d) due to contract with Government of India Postal Department for transport of postal mail from nomination date until election and after.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on the 5th March, 1952 the 1st respondent filed an election petition before the Election Commission companytesting the appellants election on the ground that the appellant was disqualified under section 7 d  of the Act as, from the date of his numberination and until the date of election and after, the appellant had a companytract with the Government of India in the Postal Department for the transport of postal mail which was a service undertaken by the Government of India.

facts.text: Appellant holds stage carriage service permit Ex. B-2 dated 26th April 1949 issued by Regional Transport Authority, Salem, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: At this stage it is necessary to state that it is admitted that the appellant is and has been the holder of a stage carriage service permit  Ex. B-2  dated the 26th April 1949, issued by the Regional Transport Authority, Salem, Madras.

facts.text: Condition of permit: if called upon, appellant will enter into agreement with Government of India for transport of postal articles and mail bags.

anchor.surface_text: It was one of the companyditions of the said permit that if called upon the appellant will enter into an agreement with the Government of India for the transport of postal articles and mail bags.

facts.text: Appellant entered registered agreement Ex. A-3 with Government of India on 16th November 1949.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of that obligation the appellant entered into a registered agreement with the Government of India on the 16th November 1949  Ex. A-3  to be numbericed in detail hereinafter.

facts.text: After appellant filed nomination paper, 1st respondent by petition dated 28th November 1951 objected to Returning Officer that nomination should be rejected as appellant had contract with GOI for transport mail Salem-Yercaud.

anchor.surface_text: After the appellant had filed his numberination paper, the 1st respondent by his petition dated the 28th November 1951 raised the objection to the effect that his numberination should be rejected on the ground that he had entered into a companytract with the Government of India for his own benefit for the transport of mail between Salem and Yercaud.

facts.text: Returning Officer for Dharmapuri PC by order Ex. A-2 dated 28th November 1951 overruled objection, holding service under imperative order Rule 160-B Madras Motor Vehicles Rules, not agreement; agreement not placed before him.

anchor.surface_text: The Returning Officer for the Dharmapuri Parliamentary Constituency, Salem, by his orders  Ex. A-2  of the same date overruled the objection holding that the service rendered by the appellant of carrying mail is number under an agreement but on an imperative order of the Government under Rule 160-B of the Madras Motor Vehicles Rules. Apparently the registered agreement  Ex. A-3  had number been placed before him.

facts.text: Appellant filed written statement on 28th May 1952 denying disqualification under section 7(d).

anchor.surface_text: To the election petition filed by the 1st respondent the appellant filed his written statement on the 28th May 1952 denying that he was disqualified for election as a member of Parliament by virtue of the provisions of section 7 d  of the Act.

facts.text: Election Tribunal framed issues: (1) Is nomination of returned candidate invalid under s.7(d) or paras 9-11 of petition? (2) Tribunal no jurisdiction due to art 103 Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: On those pleadings the following issues were framed by the Election Tribunal- Is the numberination of the 1st respt. invalid because of the prohibition companytained in section 7 d  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, or for any of the reasons set forth in paras. 9 to 11 of the petition? Has this Tribunal numberjurisdiction to decide the question as regards the disqualification of the returned candidate, because of article 103 of the Constitution of India?

facts.text: Election Tribunal decided both issues against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Both these issues were decided against the appellant.

facts.text: Election Tribunal held postal service including transport of mails is service undertaken by Central Government under s.7(d); at nomination date appellant was contractor under Central Government; agreement mutual obligations, result of mutual assent, supported by valid consideration.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal on a very elaborate discussion of the points raised before it, held that the postal service including the transport of mails is a service undertaken by the Central Government within the meaning of section 7 d  that at the date of the numberination the appellant was a companytractor under the Central Government that the agreement between the Government and the appellant involved mutual obligations which companyld number be referable to a bare statutory duty on the part of the appellant but that it was the result of mutual assent based upon a free offer and acceptance and that the agreement was supported by valid companysideration.

facts.text: Election Tribunal held article 103 Constitution not bar to its jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal also held that article 103 of the Constitution was number a bar to its jurisdiction to decide, the companytroversy.

facts.text: Election Tribunal allowed petition, held appellant's election void under s.100(1)(c) RP Act, costs to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly it allowed the election petition and held the appellants election to be void in terms of section 100 1  c  of the Act, with companyts to the respondent.

facts.text: Agreement Ex. A-3 between appellant (contractor Sri N. Sathianathan) and Governor-General of India for motor vehicle service for transit conveyance delivery postal articles mail bags from 15 Dec 1949 to 14 Dec 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The preamble says-- Whereas the said companytractor Sri. N. Sathianathan has offered to companytract with Governor-General for the provision of a Motor Vehicle Service for the transit companyveyance and delivery of all postal articles and mail bags as defined in the Indian Post Office Act, 1898, as amended from time to time, from the 15th day of December 1949 to the 14th day of December 1952 and the Governor-General has accepted such offer upon the terms and Conditions hereinafter appearing Now this indenture witnesseth that the companytractor in pursuance of the said agreement and in companysideration of the premises and of the payments hereinafter agreed to be made to him It is hereby mutually agreed and declared between and by the parties hereto as follows-

facts.text: Agreement clause: Contractor to convey postal articles mail bags by motor vehicles during contract period 15 Dec 1949 to 14 Dec 1952 or until terminated.

anchor.surface_text: Contract to carry-The companytractor shall during the companytinuance of this companytract, that is to say, from the 15th day of December 1949 until the 14th day of December 1952 or until the said companytract shall be determined by such numberice as is hereinafter men- tioned or otherwise in  hereinafter referred to as the said companytract period  duly and safely companyvey by means of motor vehicles of good and reliable manufacture all postal articles and mail bags

facts.text: Agreement Government agrees to pay contractor Rs. 200 per month remuneration, liable to increase/decrease with mileage.

anchor.surface_text: By clause 15 the Government agrees to pay to the companytractor Rs. 200 per month during the subsistence of the agreement as his remuneration for service to be rendered by him hereunder. This monthly sum of Rs. 200 is liable to be increased or decreased proportionately to the increase or decrease in the mileage to be companyered.

facts.text: Agreement clause 18: terminates if no permit renewal, no compensation; or either party 4 months notice.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 18 is in these terms- In the event of the companytractor failing to secure a renewal of the permit on the line this companytract will automatically terminate on the date up to which the old permit shall be valid and in such case numbercompensation shall be payable to either party for such termination. This companytract may be absolutely determined and put an end to by either of the companytracting parties giving four calendar months numberice in writing to the other of his intention so to determine and put an end to the same.

facts.text: Rule 160-B Madras Motor Vehicles Rules: condition of every stage carriage permit to carry mails if required by transport authority at rates/terms fixed after consultation with holder and postal authorities.

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection reference was made to rule 160-B of the Madras Motor Vehicles Rules which is as follows- It shall be a companydition of every stage carriage permit that the holder of the permit shall, if so required by the transport authority which granted the permit, carry mails at such rates and on such terms as the transport authority may fix after companysultation with the holder of the permit and the postal authorities companycerned.

facts.text: Regional Transport Officer fixed subsidy by orders dated 23rd July 1949.

anchor.surface_text: because the monetary companysideration provided for in the agreement is numbermore than the subsidy already fixed by the Regional Transport Officer by his orders dated the 23rd July, 1949

facts.text: Supreme Court held agreement Ex. A-3 is valid contract with all ingredients, appellant disqualified under s.7(d).

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid we have number the least hesitation in holding that the companyclusions arrived at by the Tribunal are entirely companyrect.

arguments.claim: Appellant disqualified under section 7(d) due to contract with Government of India for transport of postal mail, a service undertaken by the Government

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on the 5th March, 1952 the 1st respondent filed an election petition before the Election Commission contesting the appellants election on the ground that the appellant was disqualified under section 7 d  of the Act as, from the date of his nomination and until the date of election and after, the appellant had a contract with the Government of India in the Postal Department for the transport of postal mail which was a service undertaken by the Government of India.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n of the points raised before it, held that the postal service including the transport of mails is a service undertaken by the Central Government with

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal held postal service is service undertaken by Central Government; agreement involves mutual obligations, assent, consideration

arguments.claim: No disqualification as carrying mails is exclusive privilege/normal sovereign function of Government, not 'service undertaken by the Government'

anchor.surface_text: His contention was that it is the exclusive privilege of the Government of India to convey all postal articles from one place to another and it is a normal function of the Government statutorily reserved to itself. There is no justification to regard the carrying of mails from one place to another as the performance of any service undertaken by the Government.

arguments.court_reasoning: Postal service is welfare service for public convenience, not obligatory sovereign function; enabling provisions under Post Office Act

arguments.claim: No interest in contract for service under s.7(d); merely carrying out statutory obligation under Rule 160-B Madras Motor Vehicles Rules

anchor.surface_text: It was further averred on behalf of the appellant that it was not justifiable to regard him as having any interest in a contract for the performance of any service undertaken by the appropriate Government within the mischief of section 7 d  of the Act and that he had been only carrying out the obligations imposed upon him by Rule 160-B of the rules framed under the Motor Vehicles Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Lawful consideration present; separate cash consideration for postal transport distinct from permit subsidy

anchor.surface_text: In this connection reference was made to rule 160-B of the Madras Motor Vehicles Rules which is as follows- It shall be a condition of every stage carriage permit that the holder of the permit shall, if so required by the transport authority which granted the permit, carry mails at such rates and on such terms as the transport authority may fix after consultation with the holder of the permit and the postal authorities concerned.

arguments.claim: Appellant had free choice to enter contract or terminate via 4 months notice under clause 18

anchor.surface_text: Clause 18 is in these terms- In the event of the contractor failing to secure a renewal of the permit on the line this contract will automatically terminate on the date up to which the old permit shall be valid and in such case no compensation shall be payable to either party for such termination. This contract may be absolutely determined and put an end to by either of the contracting parties giving four calendar months notice in writing to the other of his intention so to determine and put an end to the same.

arguments.claim: Service rendered under imperative order of Rule 160-B, not under agreement

anchor.surface_text: The Returning Officer for the Dharmapuri Parliamentary Constituency, Salem, by his orders  Ex. A-2  of the same date overruled the objection holding that the service rendered by the appellant of carrying mail is not under an agreement but on an imperative order of the Government under Rule 160-B of the Madras Motor Vehicles Rules. Apparently the registered agreement  Ex. A-3  had not been placed before him.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t holder is number an independent companytract governed by its own special terms. As indicated above, clause 18 has reserved the right to either party

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreement Ex. A-3 placed before Tribunal; constitutes valid contract

holdings.text: we have no the least hesitation in holding that the conclusions arrived at by the Tribunal are entirely correct

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid we have no the least hesitation in holding that the conclusions arrived at by the Tribunal are entirely correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement Ex. A-3 satisfies contract essentials, concerns postal service undertaken by Central Government, appellant had direct interest at nomination; Tribunal findings on s.7(d) upheld

holdings.text: On the face of the transaction the agreement was between two competent parties with their free consent. There was no question but that there was lawful consideration
holdings.reasoning_summary: Indian Contract Act governs; parties competent, free consent via offer and acceptance, distinct cash consideration separate from permit subsidy

holdings.text: the agreement actually entered into between the Postal Department and the permit holder is an independent contract governed by its own special terms

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the permit does contain a condition that the permit-holder may be called upon to undertake transport of mail bags and postal articles but that is only a notice to intending applicants for a stage carriage permit that the grantee of such a permit may have to render that additional service for an additional remuneration if called upon to do so by the authorities of the Postal Department.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 160-B permit condition is notice to applicants; actual Ex. A-3 has mutual promises, special terms like clause 18 termination by notice

holdings.text: the Government in the Postal Department has only undertaken a service to be rendered to the community and that such a service is not an essential function of a sovereign state
holdings.reasoning_summary: Post Office Act enabling not obligatory; postal transport welfare service for public convenience, not sovereign function reserved exclusively

holdings.text: Section 7 of the Act is clearly intended to avoid a conflict between public duty and private interest

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 of the Act is clearly intended to avoid a conflict between public duty and private interest. The Tribunal discussed a number of authorities with reference to the English and the American Law of Contract for arriving at the conclusion that the agreement between the appellant and the Government of India in the Postal Department had all the ingredients of a valid contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Disqualification prevents public officials having private interests in government service contracts; appellant could terminate via notice to stand for election

holdings.text: The present case is a straightforward illustration of the kind of contract contemplated by section 7 d of the Act

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be gainsaid that the Government in the Postal Department is rendering a very useful service and that the appellant has by his contract with the Government undertaken to render that kind of service on a specified route. The present case is a straightforward illustration of the kind of contract contemplated by section 7 d of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant directly concerned for own benefit in contract for postal transport services undertaken by government at material times

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the permit does contain a condition that the permit-holder may be called upon to undertake transport of mail bags and postal articles but that is only a notice to intending applicants for a stage carriage permit that the grantee of such a permit may have to render that additional service for an additional remuneration if called upon to do so by the authorities of the Postal Department.
For the reasons aforesaid we have number the least hesitation in holding that the companyclusions arrived at by the Tribunal are entirely companyrect.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be gainsaid that the Government in the Postal Department is rendering a very useful service and that the appellant has by his contract with the Government undertaken to render that kind of service on a specified route. The present case is a straightforward illustration of the kind of contract contemplated by section 7 d of the Act.
For the reasons aforesaid we have number the least hesitation in holding that the companyclusions arrived at by the Tribunal are entirely companyrect.
